report_title: IBISWorld | Background Check Services in the US Aug 2024
executive_summary: Background check providers have enjoyed growth over the current period. The robust demand for background check services, which spans a variety of corporate clients and smaller businesses, creates a consistent demand niche for operators. Although operators continue to enjoy robust demand, shaly economic conditions and volatility in the overall labor market has affected their rate of growth. The outbreak of the pandemic and rising interest rates hindered the labor market in 2020 and 2023. Overall, revenue grew at a CAGR of 2.8% to an estimated $4.5 billion over the past five years, including an anticipated 2.1% decline in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Regulatory evolution continues to accelerate providers' demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since background check service providers are engaged in ensuring candidate validity, the effects of changing regulations play a significant role in affecting core revenue streams. Many states have begin implementing various Clean Slate Laws, which enable employment candidates to have niche criminal records be removed from consideration. Evolving rules surrounding cannabis consumption have also accelerated background check providers' appeal, with states like Minnesota easing restrictions on testing for cannabis use. Since most regulatory focus is placed on a state and local level, background check providers with excellent legal insights and strong understanding of employment laws will be better equipped in adapting to new regulatory changes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Technological innovations enabled profit to expand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Growing digitization and the release of public records on the Internet have enabled background check providers to access criminal records faster, reducing costs and improving efficiencies. The number of background check providers has fallen considerably over the current period. Competition for smaller background check providers has increased, leading many to cease operations. Since smaller background check providers typically require more employees and account for more wages, these costs have fallen over the current period amid the continued exodus of these companies. Falling wage costs strengthened profit as automated systems have replaced the need for a large workforce. Larger companies producing background checks in bulk also reduced the costs of providing them, boosting profit.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Several large companies went public and expanded their market share
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Sterling Check, HireRight and First Advantage went public in 2021, expanding market share concentration among background check providers. The companies used the proceeds of the initial public offering to repay their debt, unwind certain interest rate swaps and invest in technologies to improve operational efficiencies. Larger companies' investments in automated data collection and report generation infrastructure have paid dividends in differentiating themselves from smaller background check providers as they have increasingly attracted clients. As the importance of the quality of sources and price-based competition expanded, these companies strengthened their market share as they could produce high-quality background checks in bulk while keeping prices low.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Economic uncertainty and layoffs have had mixed effects
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Interest rate hikes have led many financial services and tech companies to lay off employees in 2022 and 2023 and reduce hiring, largely for cost-cutting imperatives amid overstaffing. Tech companies have laid off many human resource workers and financial services companies have laid off some of their back-office staff. Financial services companies laying off employees has hurt background check providers as these companies provide a consistent source of business through continuous background check services because of the high-risk nature of services. While background check providers have faced declines from companies, other industries have looked to take advantage of the influx in available tech workers, offsetting losses.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Background check providers to face headwinds in the labor market early
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As of April 2024, the labor force participation rate reached 62.7%, primarily because of an aging population and people less willing to work lower-paying jobs. Inflationary pressures will continue to stress wages and create an imbalance in the labor market early over the outlook period, as recessionary concerns create lower labor demand and fewer job openings. As the effects of the great resignation gradually subside, the labor force participation rate will increase, benefitting background check providers. As tech and finance companies ramp up rehiring after layoffs late over the current period, background check providers will enjoy a surge in growth, particularly as accelerating digitization will boost specialized background check providers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Constantly evolving regulatory environment will impact background check providers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Background check providers will continue to face a push in regulation in oversight as public concerns regarding government surveillance and the prevalence of hacking incidents expand. Increasing security concerns will prevent smaller companies that can't implement data protection measures from beginning to operate and will continue to lead to smaller companies ceasing operations. Clients will be more selective about which background check provider they choose to ensure that they comply with evolving regulations. Background check service providers' services will become more complicated as regulations evolve. While regulations have changed at the federal level, changes have also occurred at state and local levels, making it more complicated to provide services to companies with employees in different states.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consolidation and profit set to continue expanding
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As more processes become automated, employment will continue to fall over the outlook period, providing background check providers with profit growth. Competition from larger background check providers with increased automated data collection and report generation infrastructure will continue the trend of many small companies ceasing operations and disincentivizing new entrants, increasing consolidation. The number of small background check providers, which typically require more employees, ceasing operations will compound technological innovations, decreasing wages and expanding profit growth. Climbing competition from larger background check providers will disincentivize new background check providers from beginning to operate, as competing based on price and quality will be difficult.

industry_definition: The Background Check Services industry provides background screening services for employment and tenant purposes. Industry services include criminal record checks, employment and education verification, drug testing and continuous monitoring services. The industry excludes companies that solely provide credit checks or pre-employment skills testing.

products_and_services.product_description: Credit checks remain an essential service and provide consistent business. Large corporations conduct credit checks more often than small companies because of potential legal liability for negligent hiring, especially for positions with financial responsibilities.

This segment comprises criminal record check services of potential hires or tenants for businesses and landlords. Landlords and businesses conduct background checks on potential new tenants or employees to reduce liabilities. Economic volatility amid the pandemic negatively impacted this segment as businesses of all sizes conduct background checks for new employees and most businesses froze hiring in 2020.

This segment comprises reference checks of potential hires or tenants from past employers or landlords. According to the Society for Human Resources Management, 72.0% of businesses conduct in-house reference checks, hindering growth in this segment. Since reference checks don't require online systems or expertise, landlords also often conduct reference checks independently, bypassing background check providers.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Regulatory expansions put pressure on smaller companies

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Interest rate hikes pushed up other costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Background check providers pay other costs, including interest, bank charges, outsourced professional services and insurance. Climbing interest rates and large background check providers increasingly outsourcing some of their in-house services as they continue to rely less on workers has pushed up their other costs.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Rising automation led to sinking wage costs
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Technological advancements and greater access to information online have enabled background check providers to increasingly automate their processes and reduce the need for as many workers as possible.
